conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the behavior of a square wire frame in a magnetic field to determine the current and induced electromotive force (EMF).
The square wire frame has a side length L, is partially placed in a uniform magnetic field directed into the plane of the paper, and is connected to a capacitor.
The magnetic field weakens uniformly at a rate of change k, which will induce an EMF in the wire frame.
The magnetic field is represented by crosses indicating it is directed into the plane of the paper.
The magnetic field causes a current to flow in the wire frame due to the Lorentz force.
The rate of change of the magnetic field affects the induced current in the wire frame.
The induced EMF is calculated using Faraday's law: \( \Delta V = -\frac{dQ}{dt} \), where \( Q \) is the charge and \( \Delta t \) is the time interval.
Since the magnetic field is weakening uniformly, the rate of change \( \frac{dQ}{dt} \) is negative.
The induced EMF is given by \( \Delta V = -k \times L \times C \), where \( k \) is the rate of change of the magnetic field, \( L \) is the side length of the square, and \( C \) is the capacitance.
The current \( I \) is given by \( I = \frac{\Delta V}{R} \), where \( R \) is the resistance of the wire frame.
Since the current is proportional to the induced EMF, we have \( I = \frac{k \times L \times C}{R} \).
The current in the wire frame is \( I = \frac{k \times L \times C}{R} \).
The magnitude of the induced EMF is \( \Delta V = -k \times L \times C \).
The final answer is that the current in the loop is \( \frac{k \times L \times C}{R} \), and the magnitude of the induced electromotive force is \( -k \times L \times C \).
